head.title: Sounding Off on Sex Clubs; Tour Buses Damage Health And Block Roads

hedline.hl1: Sounding Off on Sex Clubs; Tour Buses Damage Health And Block Roads

abstract.p: J Chin, L Garnett and L Mosher letter on Harry M Matthews' October 18 letter scoring relocation of tour buses from Chinatown parking zone to side of Manhattan Bridge (S)

block.p: In ''Tourism, Seen From Both Sides'' (Letters, Oct. 18), Harry M. Matthews, a tour guide, complained that tour buses had to move from their Chinatown parking zone in front of our residential buildings to the side of the Manhattan Bridge.

In ''Tourism, Seen From Both Sides'' (Letters, Oct. 18), Harry M. Matthews, a tour guide, complained that tour buses had to move from their Chinatown parking zone in front of our residential buildings to the side of the Manhattan Bridge.

The stark reality is that these polluting, belching tour buses have put hard-working residents through a living hell, seven days a week. Sometimes fleets of up to 40 idling buses emit a cloud of toxic gases, which seep into our apartments, gas our children and create a choking haze in our living rooms.

These tour buses often block our streets, driveways, garage entryways and bus shelters, forcing residents out into traffic. And when we complain, bus drivers have laughed at us, grabbed our video cameras and assaulted us. After years of protest, our sympathetic Community Board 3, city and elected officials finally moved the ''bus layover zone'' to the side of the bridge.
The tour guides complain that walking an extra block and a half is too ''inconvenient.'' The real inconvenience is having to suffer through 22 years of a living nightmare.
J. CHIN, L. GARNETT and L. MOSHER Lower Manhattan
